metadata.synopsis: Still grieving over the accidental death of their daughter, Christine (Sharon Williams), John (Donald Sutherland) and Laura Baxter (Julie Christie) head to Venice, Italy, where John's been commissioned to restore a church. There Laura meets two sisters (Hilary Mason, Clelia Matania) who claim to be in touch with the spirit of the Baxters' daughter. Laura takes them seriously, but John scoffs until he himself catches a glimpse of what looks like Christine running through the streets of Venice.

reviews: Roeg's film isn't just a chiller; it's a profound study of love and grief too.
A wonderfully compelling, incredibly astounding masterpiece from Nicolas Roeg, which yields new surprises with each successive viewing.
Thanks to the steady building of tension, the most innocuous activities could become catastrophic at any moment.
[Puts] Nicolas Roeg right up at the top as a film-maker.
Fancy cutting and every other form of trickery strain to make a work of art out of Don't Look Now -- all to no avail. It doesn't pass muster even as an exercise in suspense and the supernatural.
The screenplay by Allan Scott and Chris Bryant, based on some unidentified story by Daphne Du Maurier, might have made a nice Rod Serling halfhour without all the over-edited razzle.
Unsettling thriller about grief has sex and some violence.
Separate polls by the British Film Institute and Time Out London have cited it as one of the 10 best British films ever made. No argument here.

Don't Look Now (1973) is British director Nicolas Roeg's haunting and classic "shattering" supernatural thriller (his greatest film), and depiction of grief, based upon the 1971 Daphne du Maurier short story tale.
One of the most poignant and visually stunning movies to have ever graced the horror genre.
It's clear immediately that filmmaker Nicolas Roeg isn't looking to deliver a standard, run-of-the-mill thriller here...
Roeg pulls out all the stops, producing one beautiful shot after another.

Nicolas Roeg's Don't Look Now is a stunningly crafted horror/thriller from 1973. It's a classic, a wonderfully realised piece of cinema which delivers on a dramatic and an emotional level. This is how you make a horror movie.
The whole movie is full of strange events, disturbing coincidences and impossible visions.. And all those incidents leads to a shocking, incredible and terrifying ending. [Full Review in Spanish]
The film plays the long game, and it's a game worth waiting for.

There is something molten about the whole movie. That's its magic: from the colours that shift and bleed in a transparency of a stained-glass window - Sutherland's character is a restorer of churches - to the famous, graphic love scene between the stars.
Sutherland and Christie are extraordinarily convincing as a deeply wounded but loving married couple.
Every frame is calculated perfection.
To fall under the spell of this film is to fall under the spell of two screen actors in their prime, directed by one of the great screen formalists.
Genius.
